55bb6340e3d7dd8632ba45179ae43c39f8ad0cfc.articleBody: b'T-Swift is beefing with The Carlyle Group ... what a time to be alive ...Start your day with the Opening Bell powered by The Water Coolest. The Water Coolest is the preferred bathroom stall reading material of finance professionals. Sign up for the free daily newsletter.LOOK WHAT YOU MADE ME DOBrace yourself, Swifties:\xc2\xa0Taylor Swift\xc2\xa0might not be able to perform all of her hits due to a legal dispute\xc2\xa0with Scooter Braun (which owns her former record label, Big Machine) ... and private equity giant The Carlyle Group. Wait, what?The drama began\xc2\xa0earlier this year when Braun\xe2\x80\x99s Ithaca Holdings purchased Big Machine for $300M in a deal backed by The Carlyle Group. Carlyle, which already held a stake in Ithaca, is part\xc2\xa0of a growing number of PE shops getting involved in the music industry.Why? Because, capitalism,\xc2\xa0of course.\xc2\xa0You see, owning music catalogs has become an incredibly lucrative business with the rise in streaming services. *Sharks begin circling*Back to Taylor!\xc2\xa0It\xe2\x80\x99s her music, so why can\xe2\x80\x99t she sing it?It\xe2\x80\x99s complicated.According to Swift, her former label Big Machine, which owns her masters (aka original recordings), is preventing her from performing her past hits at the American Music Awards and for an upcoming Netflix special.It\'s worth noting that it\'s not uncommon for artists to give up the rights to their original recordings. What isn\'t as common is a\xc2\xa0label\xc2\xa0not allowing an artist to perform their music. Mostly because performing the bangers (in Swift\'s case ... most of her music)\xc2\xa0benefits the owner and the artist financially.\xc2\xa0He said, she saidT-Swift took to Twitter to air her grievances with Big Machine, Braun and The Carlyle Group (what a time to be alive), recruiting fans to join her cause ... because hell hath no fury like a teenaged fangirl scorned. Big Machine has\xc2\xa0denied Swift\xe2\x80\x99s claims, saying they were \xe2\x80\x9cshocking and false.\xe2\x80\x9d And Taylor Swift fans almost broke Investopedia trying to figure out WTF private equity is.The bottom line ...Taylor Swift is ready to take her songs back and has indicated that she\xe2\x80\x99ll be re-recording her biggest hits. Yep, that\'s kosher.\xc2\xa0Which versions play on the radio and streaming services will determine how big of a blow will be dealt to Big Machine and The Carlyle Group.Moving forward, Swift has a new record deal in place with Universal Music Group, and The Carlyle Group will be left to wonder:\xc2\xa0"what did we do to deserve this?"Why Can\xe2\x80\x99t Taylor Swift Perform Her Own Songs? It\xe2\x80\x99s Complicated\xc2\xa0[Bloomberg]There\'s plenty more where that came from. Sign up for The Water Coolest today to get the free daily newsletter delivered to your inbox daily.Beyond beef. It\'s what\'s for dinner.Fake beef. It\'s what\'s for dinner.Morningstar (think veggie burgers, not research) has beef ...As if you needed an excuse to spend more time in the handicap bathroom stall at the office ...What kinda dirt did Wells have on Charlie?"What would you say ya do here?""Hi, my name is Tim and I am a lying sack of sh*t."What\'s next? \'Dashers\' demanding $15 per hour?!\n'

57b4dafd18cfd0531b69f81e87158648227c673e.articleBody:
b'Die Digitalisierung als Wachstums- und Entwicklungstreiber zieht sich bereits heute durch fast alle Branchen und Anwendungsgebiete, sei es im Finanzbereich, der Industrie oder eben auch im Bereich Healthcare.\xef\xbf\xbdAuch wenn nicht jedes Gesch\xef\xbf\xbdftsmodell von Disruption bzw. Digital Darwinismus bedroht ist, bieten neue Technologien Potenziale f\xef\xbf\xbdr mehr Effizienz, bessere Prozesse und zur Kostenersparnis. Im Bereich der Gesundheitsversorgung in Krankenh\xef\xbf\xbdusern ist dieser Aspekt ein besonders wichtiger. Durch die Festlegung von Fallpauschalen und Sonderentgelten besteht ein hoher Kostendruck. Der Bedarf an mehr Effizienz durch Digitalisierung bleibt nicht nur w\xef\xbf\xbdnschenswert, er ist zwingend notwendig. Damit das gelingt, ist der Einsatz von geeigneten interoperablen L\xef\xbf\xbdsungen entscheidend. Das Thema mit dem h\xef\xbf\xbdchsten Potenzial aber auch mit den meisten Hindernissen wird seit Jahren intensiv diskutiert: Die elektronische Patientenakte (ePA)
Status Quo
Analoge Prozesse
In Deutschland liegen Patientendaten in internen Systemen vor \x13 Sei es in Krankenhausinformationssystemen (KIS) oder im Praxisverwaltungssystem (PVS) niedergelassener \xef\xbf\xbdrzte. Auch die Dokumentation von weiteren Befunden ist in der Regel ein manueller Vorgang. Zwischen einzelnen Leistungserbringern werden Patienteninformationen, Befunde, R\xef\xbf\xbdntgenbilder teils digital, z.B. durch einrichtungsinterne Informationssysteme, aber auch analog in Form der Fieberkurve in der Behandlungskette weitergereicht. Handschriftliche Dokumentationen und postalischer Versand und Empfang sind fehleranf\xef\xbf\xbdllig. Behandelnde Mediziner sind dabei nicht immer auf dem aktuellsten Stand, erhalten wichtige Patientendaten gar nicht oder zu sp\xef\xbf\xbdt und m\xef\xbf\xbdssen Zeit f\xef\xbf\xbdr die Konsultation mit Kollegen aufwenden. Langwierige Behandlungszeitr\xef\xbf\xbdume aber auch doppelt gef\xef\xbf\xbdhrte oder unvollst\xef\xbf\xbdndige Patientenakten sind die Folge. Durch unn\xef\xbf\xbdtige \xef\xbf\xbdberbehandlung und Dokumentation sowie Behandlungsfehler entstehen so j\xef\xbf\xbdhrlich Kosten in Milliardenh\xef\xbf\xbdhe.
Einrichtungs\xef\xbf\xbdbergreifende Intransparenzen
Aufgrund des medizinischen Fortschritts sind Behandlungszentren und Einrichtungen aber auch die einzelnen Berufsgruppen im Gesundheitswesen hochdifferenziert. Je nach Diagnose und Krankheitsbild werden Untersuchungen und Therapien f\xef\xbf\xbdr Patienten in arbeitsteiligen, teils parallel ablaufenden Prozessen und \xef\xbf\xbdber mehrere Fachkliniken, Fachbereiche und Akteure abgebildet. Die so entstehenden Versorgungsketten sind zwischen den Einrichtungen nur lose bis gar nicht verzahnt, so dass es zu Br\xef\xbf\xbdchen in der Informationskette und Intransparenzen kommt. Das unzureichende oder fehlende Wissen \xef\xbf\xbdber den aktuellen Behandlungs- und Gesundheitsstatus eines Patienten erschwert die weitere Behandlung und wirkt sich negativ auf die Patientensicherheit und die Kosteneffizenz der Leistungserbringer aus. Durch fehlende Interoperabilit\xef\xbf\xbdt zwischen den unterschiedlichen Informationssystemen sind Gesundheitseinrichtungen, \xef\xbf\xbdrzte und Patienten digital voneinander entkoppelt.
Der Patient als Informationsquelle und -Verteiler
Durch die fehlende Synchronisation von Patientendaten zwischen verschiedenen Einrichtungen in der Versorgungskette kommt dem Patienten eine besondere Rolle als Informations\xef\xbf\xbdbermittler zu. Einerseits muss er m\xef\xbf\xbdglichst l\xef\xbf\xbdckenlos \xef\xbf\xbdber seine bisherige Krankengeschichte (je nach Fall \xef\xbf\xbdber mehrere Jahre in die Vergangenheit) berichten k\xef\xbf\xbdnnen aber auch medizinisches Fachpersonal hinsichtlich bestehender Vorerkrankungen, Medikation, Unvertr\xef\xbf\xbdglichkeiten, Allergien, etc. aufkl\xef\xbf\xbdren k\xef\xbf\xbdnnen. Gerade bei \xef\xbf\xbdlteren oder geistig beeintr\xef\xbf\xbdchtigten Patienten sind Informationsl\xef\xbf\xbdcken oft unvermeidlich. Zus\xef\xbf\xbdtzlich werden Dokumente wie Arztbriefe oder Ergebnisse aus bildgebenden Verfahren dem Patienten bei der Entlassung/\xef\xbf\xbdberstellung pers\xef\xbf\xbdnlich mitgegeben. Damit tr\xef\xbf\xbdgt der Patient auch selbst ein unn\xef\xbf\xbdtig hohes Ma\xef\xbf\xbd an Verantwortung f\xef\xbf\xbdr einen optimalen Behandlungsverlauf und dessen Dauer.
Die elektronische Patientenakte (ePA) soll diesen Herausforderungen begegnen und bildet aktuell das Kernthema in deutschen Krankenh\xef\xbf\xbdusern und Pflegeeinrichtungen\xef\xbf\xbdin puncto Digitalisierung des Gesundheitswesens.
Die elektronische Patientenakte \x13 viele Modelle und kaum Vernetzung
Aktuelle Situation
Bereits 2004 mit dem GKV-Modernisierungsgesetz wurde die ePA als eine der Anwendungen der elektronischen Gesundheitskarte (eGK) genannt. Seit dem wurde mehr als eine Milliarde Euro in das Projekt investiert und noch immer nutzen Patienten in Deutschland keine elektronische Gesundheitskarte.
In dem 2015 verabschiedeten E-Health-Gesetz wurde die ePA als wesentlicher Teil der k\xef\xbf\xbdnftigen Telematikinfrastruktur (TI) genannt. Die TI, welche von der Betriebsgesellschaft gematik entwickelt wird, soll dabei das digitale Kommunikationsnetz und die Grundlage f\xef\xbf\xbdr die ePA und das elektronische Patientenfach bilden. Bis zum 01.01.2019 sollen alle \xef\xbf\xbdrzte, Psychotherapeuten, Krankenh\xef\xbf\xbduser und anderen Akteure des Gesundheitswesens daran angebunden sein.\xef\xbf\xbd
Laut Gesetz soll die ePA den Not\xef\xbf\xbdfall\xef\xbf\xbddaten\xef\xbf\xbdsatz, den Medikationsplan, Arztbriefe und weitere medizinische Dokumente, wie etwa den elektronischen Impfpass, aufnehmen.
Anders als das ebenfalls vorgesehene ePF, erfordert die ePA als Zugriffsberechtigung den elektronischen Heilberufsausweis des behandelnden Arztes. Im ePF wiederrum sollen dem Versicherten die Inhalte seiner Patientenakte in ein sogenanntes Patientenfach gespiegelt werden, damit der Patient auch unabh\xef\xbf\xbdngig von einem Arztbesuch darauf zugreifen kann. \xef\xbf\xbdber die Daten der Akte hinaus, soll der Patient hier auch die M\xef\xbf\xbdglichkeit erhalten, pers\xef\xbf\xbdnliche Gesundheitsdaten einzutragen.\xef\xbf\xbd
Mit einheitlichen Standards und Spezifikationen sollen Insell\xef\xbf\xbdsungen vermieden werden. Im E-Health Gesetz ist davon allerdings nichts zu lesen. Daf\xef\xbf\xbdr existierten heute bereits parallel verschiedene gesetzliche Grundlagen zur Umsetzung von elektronischen Akten:

In \xef\xbf\xbd 291a Absatz 3 Nr. 4 SGB V - elektronische Patientenakte
in \xef\xbf\xbd 291a Absatz 3 Nr. 5 SGB V - elektronisches Patientenfach
in \xef\xbf\xbd 68 SGB V - elektronische Gesundheitsakte
in \xef\xbf\xbd 630f BGB \x13 elektronische Arztakte

Milliardenschwere Digitalprojekte auf Basis von confusion-by-design haben es schwer. Daher ist es auch nicht verwunderlich, dass bereits ein E-Health Gesetz II in Arbeit ist. In der Zwischenzeit haben bereits einige Versicherer Ihre eigenen Pilotprojekte in Betrieb genommen. Nat\xef\xbf\xbdrlich mit unterschiedliche Strategien und mit unterschiedlichen Varianten der elektronischen Patientenakte.
Varianten von Patientenakten\xef\xbf\xbd

Einrichtungs\xef\xbf\xbdbergreifende Patientenakte (eEPA) Bei diesem Konzept werden alle Informationen die bei der Behandlungen eines Patienten anfallen f\xef\xbf\xbdr Gesundheitsversorgungseinrichtungen fall\xef\xbf\xbdbergreifend hinweg bereitgestellt. Eintragungen erfolgen ausschlie\xef\xbf\xbdlich \xef\xbf\xbdber \xef\xbf\xbdrzte und \xef\xbf\xbdhnliche Behandlungsmitglieder. Die Akte wird dauerhaft gef\xef\xbf\xbdhrt, so dass eine gesamtheitliche Versorgung des Patienten \xef\xbf\xbdber alle bisherigen oder bestehenden Krankheiten m\xef\xbf\xbdglich ist. Eintr\xef\xbf\xbdge k\xef\xbf\xbdnnen von Leistungserbringern \xef\xbf\xbdber ein Portal oder \xef\xbf\xbdber das Prim\xef\xbf\xbdrsystem heraus an die eEPA \xef\xbf\xbdbermittelt werden \x13 Die Interoperabilit\xef\xbf\xbdt zwischen den Systemen vorausgesetzt. Die eEPA sieht abseits von der Datenfreigabe keine Einsicht oder Mitwirkung durch den Patienten selbst vor.



Elektronische Fallakte (eFA)Die eFA ist \xef\xbf\xbdrztlich gef\xef\xbf\xbdhrt und moderiert. Sie wird einrichtungs\xef\xbf\xbdbergreifend eingesetzt und ausschlie\xef\xbf\xbdlich fallbezogen gef\xef\xbf\xbdhrt. Die eFA hat zum Ziel, eine optimale Koordination der Versorgung in den einzelnen Behandlungseinrichtungen zu erm\xef\xbf\xbdglichen. Im Gegensatz zur eEPA wird sie nach Fallabschluss geschlossen, der Lebenszyklus der Akte f\xef\xbf\xbdllt dementsprechend kurz aus. Die Daten in der eFA werden \xef\xbf\xbdber die Prim\xef\xbf\xbdrsysteme zur Verf\xef\xbf\xbdgung gestellt. Auch hier gibt der Patient seine Einwilligung \xef\xbf\xbdber die Datennutzung generell, ein Zugriff auf Patientenseite findet nicht statt.


Pers\xef\xbf\xbdnliche, einrichtungs\xef\xbf\xbdbergreifende Gesundheits- und\xef\xbf\xbdPatientenakte (PEPA)Dieses Konzept bindet den Patienten bei der Bereitstellung, Einsicht und Freigabe von Gesundheitsdaten aktiv mit ein. \xef\xbf\xbdber ein Patientenportal hat der Patient die M\xef\xbf\xbdglichkeit z.B. Arztbriefe selbstst\xef\xbf\xbdndig einzustellen (Patienten-Selbstmanagement). Auch hat der Patient die M\xef\xbf\xbdglichkeit selbst zu bestimmen, welche Daten in der Akte gespeichert werden und wer darauf Zugriff haben soll. Die PEPA ist wie die ePA eine fall\xef\xbf\xbdbergreifende bzw. lebenslange Akte und wird sowohl vom Patienten als auch \xef\xbf\xbdrzten dezentral oder \xef\xbf\xbdber angebundene Prim\xef\xbf\xbdrsysteme gepflegt.\xef\xbf\xbd



Elektronische Gesundheitsakte (eGA) Die elektronische Gesundheitsakte wird h\xef\xbf\xbdufig mit der elektronischen Patientenakte gleichgesetzt. Da letztere aber bis auf die PEPA rein \xef\xbf\xbdrztlich gef\xef\xbf\xbdhrt ist, ist die eGA so ausgelegt, dass der Patient alleiniger Herr seiner Daten ist und diese beliebig anreichern kann. Versicherte sollen selbst entscheiden k\xef\xbf\xbdnnen, welche Diagnosen oder Medikamente sie darauf speichern m\xef\xbf\xbdchten und wem sie Einsicht gew\xef\xbf\xbdhren wollen. Voraussetzung ist, dass die eGA das Erheben, Verarbeiten und Nutzen von Daten \xef\xbf\xbdber Befunde, Diagnosen, Therapien, Behandlungsberichte sowie Impfungen f\xef\xbf\xbdr eine fall- und einrichtungs\xef\xbf\xbdbergreifende Dokumentation \xef\xbf\xbdber den Patienten unterst\xef\xbf\xbdtzt

Technische Standards
Aus der Notwendigkeit einer einheitlichen Kommunikation und der Herstellung von Interoperabilit\xef\xbf\xbdt, haben sich verschiedene Standards entwickelt, die den technischen Kontext f\xef\xbf\xbdr elektronische Patientenakten bilden.

Integrating the Healthcare Enterprise (IHR)IHE ist eine internationale, gemeinn\xef\xbf\xbdtzige Initiative aus Industrie und Fachanwendern, die sich zum Ziel gesetzt hat, die Interoperabilit\xef\xbf\xbdt zwischen IT-Systemen im Gesundheitswesen sicherzustellen. Die von IHE entwickelten Standards (IHE-Profile) unterst\xef\xbf\xbdtzen eine Vielzahl klinischer Prozesse und enthalten auch optionale Funktionen und sind bestimmten Dom\xef\xbf\xbdnen z.B. f\xef\xbf\xbdr Augenheilkunde, Radiologie, Technische Infrastruktur, etc. zugeordnet. F\xef\xbf\xbdr den Einsatz von elektronischen Patientenakten ist das IHE Profil XDS (Cross-Enterprise Dokument Sharing) hervorzuheben, welches eine standardisierte Spezifikation f\xef\xbf\xbdr die gemeinsame, einrichtungs\xef\xbf\xbdbergreifende Nutzung von Dokumenten beschreibt.\xef\xbf\xbd


HL7 HL7 ist, \xef\xbf\xbdhnlich wie IHR, eine internationale Gruppe, die einheitliche Standards f\xef\xbf\xbdr den Datenaustausch zwischen verschiedenen Gesundheitsinstitutionen- und Systemen entwickelt. Die entwickelten Normen haben die Interoperabilit\xef\xbf\xbdt von verschiedenen Herstellern und Betreibern zum Ziel z.B. zwischen Krankenhausinformationssystemen (KIS) und Praxisverwaltungssystemen (PVS) niedergelassener \xef\xbf\xbdrzte. Der aktuellste Standard FHIR (Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources) vereinigt die Vorteile der etablierten HL7-Standard-Produktlinien und aktuellen Web-Standards (z.B. XML, JSON, ATOM, HTTPS, OAuth) und legt Wert auf einfache Implementierbarkeit und unterst\xef\xbf\xbdtzt die Entwicklung von mobile und cloud-basierte Anwendungen.
DICOM\xef\xbf\xbd DICOM\xef\xbf\xbd steht f\xef\xbf\xbdr Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine und ist der internationale Standard zum \xef\xbf\xbdbertragen, Speichern, Abrufen, Drucken, Verarbeiten und Anzeigen von medizinischen Bildinformationen. Die meisten Hersteller von Systeme f\xef\xbf\xbdr bildgebende Verfahren wie R\xef\xbf\xbdntgen, MRT, CT haben den Standard in ihren Produkten implementiert. Dadurch wird eine hohe Interoperabilit\xef\xbf\xbdt im Umfeld verschiedener Gesundheitseinrichtungen erm\xef\xbf\xbdglicht. DICOM bildet auch die Grundlage f\xef\xbf\xbdr die digitale Bildarchivierungsystemen sog. Picture Archiving and Communication Systems (PACS).

Aktuelle Praxisbeispiele
Vivy-App
Die vom gleichnamigen Unternehmen entwickelte App \x1eVivy\x1c wurde in Kooperation von 90 gesetzlichen Krankenkassen und vier privaten Krankenversicherungen auf den Weg gebracht. Die in einem deutschen Rechenzentrum gespeicherten Daten sind Ende-zu-Ende verschl\xef\xbf\xbdsselt und k\xef\xbf\xbdnnen \xef\xbf\xbdber ein gekoppeltes Smartphone mit 2-Faktor-Authentifizierung vom Patienten eingesehen werden. Die App erm\xef\xbf\xbdglicht den Upload von medizinischen Daten und Dokumenten. Die App soll nicht nur die Gesundheitsakte sondern zudem den Impfpass, den Medikationsplan, Notfalldaten, einen\xef\xbf\xbd Gesundheits-Check sowie eine Arztsuche beinhalten. Mittels Barcode-Scan von Medikamenten sollen auch m\xef\xbf\xbdgliche Wechselwirkungen aufgezeigt werden. Da die App das DICOM-Format beherrscht, k\xef\xbf\xbdnnen auch Daten wie aus bildgebenden Verfahren importiert werden. Der Patient entscheidet, welche Informationen er mit \xef\xbf\xbdrzten und Gesundheitseinrichtungen teilt und kann auch Dokumente l\xef\xbf\xbdschen. Beim Verlust des Schl\xef\xbf\xbdssel sind die Daten allerdings unwiederbringlich verloren. Vivy soll als pers\xef\xbf\xbdnliche Gesundheitsassistent-App f\xef\xbf\xbdr 25 Mio. Versicherte kostenfrei zur Verf\xef\xbf\xbdgung gestellt werden.\xef\xbf\xbd
'

57d46c9d751e3fd3ffaf3ede7ac20cebd30eacb5.articleBody: b'NEW YORK (Reuters) - Oil prices fell sharply on Tuesday on oversupply concerns, while a gauge of stocks across the globe rose for a seventh straight session after large overnight gains in Asia. FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., November 18, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermidThe U.S. benchmark S&P 500 index was little changed, the blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average fell and the Nasdaq rose, all having hit record intraday highs earlier in the session. Traders cited the lingering uncertainty over whether the United States and China could agree to end a near 1-1/2 year trade war as a reason for stocks to drift and bond prices to go higher. U.S. President Donald Trump said he would raise tariffs on Chinese imports if no deal is reached with Beijing to end the trade war. The next round of tariffs is due to start in mid-December. Oil fell after sources told Reuters that Russia is unlikely to agree to cut its oil output further at a meeting with fellow exporters next month. Separately, Norway\x19s October oil production beat forecasts and the potential oversupply, combined with some worries over global demand next year, sent prices lower. \x1cMoreover, Russia also failed to fulfill its agreed cuts in November so far,\x1d Commerzbank analyst Carsten Fritsch said. U.S. crude CLc1 fell 3.38% to $55.12 per barrel and Brent LCOc1 was last at $60.73, down 2.74% on the day. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average .DJI fell 102.2 points, or 0.36%, to 27,934.02, the S&P 500 .SPX lost 1.85 points, or 0.06%, to 3,120.18 and the Nasdaq Composite .IXIC added 20.72 points, or 0.24%, to 8,570.66. Hopes of a trade truce earlier in the day drove European stocks to a four-year high and a measure of world stock markets to their highest in nearly two years, but those gains were pared later in the session. The pan-European STOXX 600 index lost 0.12% while MSCI\x19s gauge of stocks across the globe .MIWD00000PUS gained 0.02% eking out its seventh straight session of gains. Emerging market stocks rose 0.48%. MSCI\x19s broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan .MIAPJ0000PUS closed 0.68% higher, while Japan\x19s Nikkei futures NKc1 lost 0.66%. Long-dated U.S. Treasury yields slipped as risk appetite weakened. Benchmark 10-year notes US10YT=RR last rose 7/32 in price to yield 1.786%, down from 1.808% late on Monday. The 30-year bond US30YT=RR last rose 29/32 in price to yield 2.252%, from 2.293% late on Monday. The dollar was little changed against a basket of six major currencies. The dollar index .DXY rose 0.05%, with the euro EUR= up 0.05% to $1.1075. While the dollar was supported by recent U.S. economic data meeting lowered expectations, the greenback may be in for some weakness, said Juan Perez, senior foreign exchange trader and strategist at Tempus Inc. \x1cCentral banks cannot provide that much to incentivize stocks any higher, thus risk-appetite is muted and the buck may continue to lose based on the fact that the American economy is indeed slower and the Fed\x19s ability to satisfy anyone is in question,\x1d Perez said. The Japanese yen strengthened 0.13% versus the greenback at 108.55 per dollar, while Sterling GBP= was last trading at $1.2925, down 0.21% on the day. Spot gold XAU= added 0.1% to $1,472.19 an ounce. Copper CMCU3 rose 0.86% to $5,880.00 a tonne. Three-month aluminum on the London Metal Exchange CMAL3 lost 0.06% to $1,737.00 a tonne. (Graphic: Global assets in 2019 - here) (Graphic: Global currencies vs. dollar - here) (Graphic: Emerging markets in 2019 - here) Reporting by Rodrigo Campos; additional reporting by Stephanie Kelly, Saqib Iqbal Ahmed and Gertrude Chavez-Dreyfuss; Editing by Nick Zieminski and Dan GreblerOur Standards:The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles.\n'

57e2e98887a1965689955921208e32f410b10e2b.articleBody:
b' New York, NY \x13 With content engagement migrating from desktop to mobile devices, my6sense, a comprehensive, white label programmatic native ad platform and exchange, is adding mobile marketing pioneer Ivan Braiker as the company\x19s first Chief Strategy Officer.
Ivan served as the CEO of Hipcricket, a mobile marketing company which innovated mobile messaging as a marketing vehicle, from 2004 \x13 2014, achieving a successful exit for the company\x19s investors by selling Hipcricket to Augme Technologies in 2011. Ivan led that company as it secured leading Fortune 100 brands as clients including Ford, Macy\x19s, Kellogg\x19s, NBC, Fox and others, and won awards from Frost & Sullivan, CTIA and Ernst & Young.
\x1cWe\x19re excited to have Ivan join our team as Chief Strategy Officer, bringing to my6sense his 25 years of management experience in mobile and media, most notably from Hipcricket,\x1d said Avinoam Rubinstain, CEO and founder of my6sense. \x1cWith our enhanced AI technology and strong growth in Europe and the Americas, my team and I are looking forward to using Ivan\x19s insight and experience to enable us to navigate the expansion my6sense is experiencing.\x1d
Research from my6sense, which is enabling over 100 ad serving and media group clients to improve performance and user experience through better optimization, relevancy and personalization and has proved that a range of recommendation widgets, in-feed and in-ad native ad units, provide the best performance for both supply and demand-side clients and partners.
\x1cWith new clients coming on board driven by my6sense\x19s proprietary AI technology, it\x19s an exciting time for me to be joining Avinoam and his team as they scale their native, programmatic offering to support a growing list of supply and demand side partners utilizing a range of ad units and solutions,\x1d said Ivan Braiker, my6sense\x19s new Chief Strategy Officer.
my6sense is the only fully programmatic native exchange solution for multi-item native ad units combined with comprehensive organic content recirculation. my6sense\x19s clients and partners can easily mix recommendation widgets, in-feed, in-ad and any other custom native ad units with any number of ad items and units on a page, knowing that the platform\x19s powerful AI and exchange technologies will optimize paid ads and organic content for the best performance and user experience.
The my6sense white label programmatic native solution includes a full native exchange that works with native Demand Side Platforms (DSPs) such as StackAdapt, built-in direct campaign manager for advertisers and as an ad unit and yield manager for publishers. In addition, the company\x19s solutions provide hierarchical business management tools for ad networks and media and publisher groups as well as comprehensive ad quality classifications and control, performance optimization and advanced policy rules. Flexible configurations used by my6sense\x19s partners include a white label native ad network and exchange, an owned and managed private exchange for group publishers, and cross-network programmatically traded supply and demand.
About my6sense
my6sense offers an open programmatic white-label native advertising platform for ad networks, media trading companies, group publishers, DSPs and SSPs. The company\x19s highly specialized technology combines the best of what is offered by both traditional native and advanced programmatic ecosystems, offering the best of both worlds in one, holistic, end-to-end solution. As a white label, ready-to-implement, fully featured solution, my6sense\x19s flexible model works with any business blueprint, supports all ad units and comes equipped with a suite of tools for full control and customization. Digital Intuition\xef\xbf\xbd, the company\x19s powerful patented optimization algorithm, provides advanced content personalization by optimizing the performance of both organic content and native ads. my6sense\x19s Cross-Network Exchange offers out-of-the-box scalability by interconnecting media groups and third party demand and supply providers with an open programmatic RTB exchange. For more information, please visit\xef\xbf\xbdwww.my6sense.com. 
'

5a822960e9a2cb1e664d334b6c936c5cb6e41fb5.articleBody: b'VIENNA \x14 The house where Adolf Hitler was born will be turned into a police station, Austria\'s interior minister said on Tuesday, after years of debate over how best to prevent it becoming a pilgrimage site for neo-Nazis.Having recently carried out a compulsory purchase of the house in Braunau am Inn, a town on the border with Germany, Austria will invite architects to submit plans for a redesign of the building. It will house the local police force\'s offices, the Interior Ministry said in a statement."The house\'s future use by the police should send an unmistakable signal that this building will never again evoke the memory of National Socialism," Interior Minister Wolfgang Peschorn, who serves in a provisional government of civil servants, said in the statement.Architects from across the European Union will be invited to submit plans for the building\'s redesign this month and a jury of experts and public officials will pick the winning design in the first half of next year, the Interior Ministry said.Although Hitler was born in Braunau in 1889, Austria argued for decades that it was the first victim of National Socialism, having been annexed by Hitler\'s Germany in 1938.Recent governments have, however, recognized that Austrians were also perpetrators of Nazi crimes and that there was little resistance to Hitler\'s rule.\n'

5ae11e580afc12d3ba1a12944281e6a7a5dded5c.articleBody:
b'\xef\xbf\xbd
BAAR, SWITZERLAND
Based on Ascom\x19s connectivity, clinical workflow and mobility expertise, the Digistat Patient Watch solution provides clinicians throughout Europe with an innovative solution to address the needs of Intensive Care Units (ICUs). This partnership further expands the existing global relationship between GE and Ascom.
In traditional ICUs, each patient is wired to up to ten medical equipment \x13 from monitoring devices to ventilators or infusion pumps. These high-end technologies provide clinicians with critical information and alert them when staff intervention is required. But this can sometimes lead to alarm fatigue, with care givers being exposed to up to 1,000 alarms per shift[1], even though up to 99% of those do not even require clinical intervention[2].
The new alarm management solution called Digistat Patient Watch, collects data from a variety of devices connected to the patient providing a holistic view at the patient bedside level and at the ICU level. Clinicians gain visibility on patient status, highlighting alarms and warnings occurring on any connected device. This critical data can also be displayed on a handheld mobile device, such as the Ascom Myco 2 which is designed specifically for clinical staff. The benefits for healthcare professionals may include helping improve staff efficiency, supporting better organization of patient care and implementing procedures to reduce the number of alarms.
\x1cDigistat Patient Watch helps clinicians leverage patient data to increase situational awareness and align priorities. It has the potential to change their practice and improve workflow efficiency\x1d says Andr\xef\xbf\xbd Neu, Head of Platform Solutions for Ascom.
\x1cDigistat Patient Watch is an important addition to GE Healthcare\x19s portfolio of solutions for the Intensive Care, and we are delighted with this expanded collaboration with Ascom\x1d, adds Olivier Bosc, General Manager of Life Care Solutions Europe at GE Healthcare.
For more information on the Digistat Patient Watch solution, as well as on Ascom\x19s innovative clinical care solutions, please visit: www.ascom.com
[1] Alarm fatigue: impacts on patient safety, Ruskin KJ, Hueske-Kraus D. Curr Opin Anaesthesiol. 2015; 28: 685-690.
[2] Joint Commission National Patient Safety Goal: Alarm Management |ECRI top 10 Health Technology Hazard
\xef\xbf\xbd

'

5caf91b8a4423735f866b089d2611ea14503584c.articleBody: b'    HAYWARD, Calif. (AP) \xe2\x80\x94 The Latest on a deadly stabbing on a San Francisco Bay Area commuter train (all times local):  10 p.m.  Authorities say a stabbing that killed a passenger on a San Francisco Bay Area commuter train may have occurred after the attacker tried to steal another rider\xe2\x80\x99s shoes.  The fight broke out Tuesday afternoon on a BART train pulling into a station in Hayward.  The San Francisco Chronicle says police are looking into whether the victim was a good Samaritan who tried to stop the suspect from stealing items from another person, possibly shoes.   The man ran from the station. The Chronicle says he was arrested a block away after employees of a car dealership said he tried to steal a van.  Employee Steve Castro tells the paper that he fought with the shirtless man, who snatched the keys from his hand as he was showing the van to a customer.      ___  4:14 p.m.  A California transit chief says a man has been stabbed to death on a San Francisco Bay Area commuter train during a fight.  Interim BART Police Chief Ed Alvarez told reporters at a news conference that officials began receiving 911 calls Tuesday afternoon about a fight aboard a train between two men.  He says transit officers boarded the train at the next stop and found a man bleeding, who was possibly the victim of a stabbing. He says the man died.  Alvarez says transit officers quickly searched the area and were able to apprehend a suspect.  He said there is no threat to the public because it was a fight between two people who engaged each other.   Officials did not immediately provide any other details.  \n'

5f9c5ed5d64dfe682d9bde13b9b4f032a3ebdbf1.articleBody:
b'
NEW DELHI: Their American dream shattered and huge savings wasted, nearly 150 Indians returned home broke on Wednesday after being deported for either violating visa norms or illegally entering the United States.\xef\xbf\xbdAs they stepped outside the airport, one after the other, they appeared sad. Some said they felt dejected that they could not realise their American dream even after several attempts.
\x1cThis was the fourth time I have been deported,\x1d said Singh Jabarjung, 24, from Punjab\x19s Bhatinda.
\x1cI boarded a flight on May 15 and reached Mexico via Moscow and Paris. From there, I tried to enter California on May 16 but was caught by police and deported from Arizona,\x1d he said.
He said he has spent Rs 24 lakh in the four attempts and Rs 40 lakh on advocacy. Lakshiwnder Singh, another deportee, said he had given Rs 25 lakh to an Amritsar-based agent to help him enter the US.\xef\xbf\xbd\x1cHe sent me to Mexico on May 2 via Moscow and Paris. They caught me while I was trying to cross the border and deported here from Arizona in US,\x1d he said.
The special aircraft carrying the deportees landed at the T3 terminal of the Delhi airport at 6am, an airport official said. The aircraft reached India via Bangladesh. Following paper work with the immigration department, the deportees have started coming out of the airport. These 150 Indians have either violated their visa norms or were illegal immigrants, the officials said.
On October 18, more than 300 Indians, including one woman, were deported by Mexican immigration authorities for illegally entering the country to sneak into the US. PTI

5fa3154ec031ab35411a457d78eb5aa92c0e803c.articleBody:
b'
Hong Kong is burning. The authorities continue to pour fuel on the fire. On Monday, the People\x19s Daily, the mouthpiece of the Communist party, warned that there is \x1cabsolutely no room for compromise\x1d. But it is not merely that Beijing and the Hong Kong government will not take a step back; they continue to escalate the crisis.
As the newspaper commentary was published, Hong Kong Polytechnic University was besieged by police, who fired round after round of teargas at protesters attempting to flee the scene. The message \x13 no way out \x13 was all the more disturbing given that officers had earlier threatened to use live fire if petrol bombs or weaponry were used against them again. Among the hundreds trapped were said to be secondary school pupils. Parents, lawmakers and a bishop who sought to talk to protesters and seek some kind of resolution were prevented from doing so, though the former head of Hong Kong\x19s legislative council was later allowed to enter. When tens of thousands more residents launched \x1csave the students\x1d marches converging upon the campus, they too faced rubber bullets and teargas, in some cases after people threw petrol bombs.
Excessive force and police brutality have accelerated and magnified these protests, turning what began as a rejection of the extradition bill into a far broader movement, and persuading a large section of the population that they should support it. The withdrawal of the bill was far too little, too late. Meanwhile, banning most rallies has closed off a peaceful avenue for challenging authorities.
Though many remain peaceful, a radical minority of protesters have responded with unacceptable violence. Many in Hong Kong will deplore that decision and were rightly repelled when a man was set on fire last week, apparently by a protester. Another man died after he was hit by a brick during a clash between protesters and police. But a large proportion of the population still blames those in power for this crisis, and it is likely that more stand by the cause: defending Hong Kong\x19s way of life, safeguarded in theory until 2047, but dramatically eroded in recent years. Meanwhile, they note that the People\x19s Liberation Army took to the city\x19s streets to clear barricades this weekend: a \x1cvoluntary clean-up activity\x1d which acted as a reminder that the Chinese military could yet be called in, and which many saw as an attempt to normalise their presence.
The movement\x19s resolve in Hong Kong is also a response to events on the mainland: the increasing repression seen under Xi Jinping, most of all in Xinjiang. As government documents leaked to the New York Times have unveiled, the mass detention of a million or more Uighurs and other minorities originated in directives from Xi to \x1cshow absolutely no mercy\x1d in the \x1cstruggle against terrorism, infiltration and separatism\x1d. Many in Hong Kong fear that to pause or seek compromise is to surrender entirely. Further repression in the region will provoke the kind of ongoing resistance, even insurgency, that some have called the \x1cBelfastisation\x1d of the city.
Further afield, the crisis has boosted, to Beijing\x19s chagrin, the prospects of Taiwan\x19s incumbent president, Tsai Ing-wen of the Democratic Progressive party, as she faces next year\x19s election. And the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act, under consideration by the US Senate on Monday, would impose economic sanctions and a travel ban on officials deemed responsible for human rights abuses.
China\x19s leaders may still believe all this is a price worth paying. Since 1989, when it crushed the pro-reform protests that began in Tiananmen Square, and witnessed the beginning of the end for the Soviet Union, Beijing has calculated that bloody suppression should be avoided if possible \x13 but not by offering concessions. It will angrily dismiss any criticism, as it has that from Britain. Ignored or not, foreign leaders have a duty to remind China that they are watching.



'

5fa5679de56c43edf70685762c2d1f2de296432a.articleBody: b'The big iFixit teardown is done, and the results are in. The new 16-inch MacBook Pro is a heck of a lot like the old 15-inch MacBook Pro, save for a few meaningful throwback features. Yes, I mean throwback as in retro\x14as in Apple actually took retired features from old MacBooks and reintroduced them as new features. It would seem that the future of innovation at the Cupertino-based computer company is what I\x19ll call rewind design.I\x19m not complaining. The 16-inch MacBook Pro looks like a hell of a laptop, as it should for a starting price of $2,400. The new machine comes with a bigger display, a bigger battery, better speakers, and a brand new AMD graphics card. Then there are those retro features. There\x19s a physical escape button just like there was on MacBook Pros before the rise of the Touch Bar. The arrow keys are once again arranged in an inverted \x1cT\x1d formation, as they had been on keyboards for decades. The new \x1cMagic Keyboard\x1d uses a scissor switch that\x19s almost identical to the Bluetooth-enabled Magic Keyboard that Apple released nearly five years ago. The keyboard thing is a big deal. Apple has been dealing with public outrage sparked by its newer butterfly mechanism in MacBook keyboards. This low-travel design contributed to the impossible thinness of the 12-inch MacBook released in 2015, before finding its way into all MacBook models in 2016. Even a small bit of dust or debris could disable a key, and fixing it required replacing the entire upper half of the laptop. Apple admitted to the flawed design and launched a limited repair program in June 2018, before it ultimately offered free keyboard repairs for all MacBooks with the new mechanism. The company was still trying to fix the scissor design as recently as May of this year when it launched an updated 15-inch MacBook Pro. Now, the cursed butterfly-powered MacBook keyboard is all but dead. The new keyboard design is expected to show up on smaller MacBooks in early 2020.But the new design isn\x19t all that new. As iFixit points out in its teardown, the 16-inch MacBook\x19s keyboard is virtually identical to the well-loved Magic Keyboard from 2o15. In other words, Apple replaced a flawed design from 2015\x14one that it had tried and failed to perfect many times\x14with a design from 2015 that wasn\x19t so flawed. It\x19s almost as if Apple made the wrong decision almost five years ago, and in order to deal with that, it\x19s just going back in time and making the right decision. The same is true for the new physical escape button, which Apple had axed on most MacBook Pro models in 2016, and for the new inverted \x1cT\x1d arrow key layout, which Apple had done away with back in 2015.Photo: iFixitThis is a curious way to design computers. It also seems like Apple\x19s MacBook team was really screwing up back in 2015. That was a time when the company\x19s design team decided to fix a few things that weren\x19t broken and break a few more things in the process. Now, to fix those problems, Apple is just replacing the broken new things with near-identical versions of the old things, effectively putting its design process in reverse. If you liked the crispiness and ease of the newer scissor mechanism on the big MacBook Pro, too bad. Apple failed at perfecting its promising design so it just switched back to the old one.Once again,\xef\xbf\xbdI\x19m not complaining. As one of the many thousands of people with broken MacBook keyboards, I welcome the return of the more robust design of the Magic Keyboard. I have one of the old Magic Keyboards on my desk, and I love it! I especially love how the keys don\x19t break constantly. And while we\x19re on the topic, I also miss having an escape key. My 15-inch MacBook Pro has a Touch Bar, which I hate\x14although I would hate it slightly less if it had a physical escape key. I\x19m honestly impartial on the inverted \x1cT\x1d arrow key thing, but I know some people are passionate about it.What does bug me about Apple\x19s new take on innovation is that it confirms the belief that the company seldom has new ideas. I wrote a long rant about this last year when it was apparent that Apple focuses less on hardware innovation and more on money-making services. That prediction, unfortunately, turned out to be true. In recent months, we\x19ve seen the release of a new iPhone, which amounted to the old iPhone plus an extra camera, as well as the new Apple TV+ streaming service, which is a bit bland. They\x19re not bad products. But they\x19re certainly not groundbreaking.The same appears to be true for the 16-inch MacBook Pro. I\x19ll reserve final judgment until I\x19ve had time to test the new laptop, and given my penchant for an operational keyboard and an escape key, I bet I\x19ll like it. I just can\x19t stop wondering if I\x19ll ever see another new Apple product that warps my understanding of technology the way that the iPod or the iPhone did so many years ago. It\x19s possible that Apple will do it with some sort of augmented reality headset in the next couple of years. Maybe its designers have been so busy working on that futuristic product that they couldn\x19t focus on perfecting keyboard design. Surely they\x19ve been busy doing better things.\n'

5fbc7ccb504c755ae23a85499a17518483d7862b.articleBody: b"  (Image: gargantiopa / Getty Images)  As the year comes to an end, it's time to sit back and reflect. This year we saw Samsung almost fold the Fold, the Motorola Razr make a comeback, and Apple impresses with the iPhone 11's camera. We also saw gadgets from tech companies, large and small, that made a splash over the past year.\xef\xbf\xbdAlso: See Black Friday coverage at CNETSurely, as we head into the season of Black Friday and Cyber Monday, along with the many promotions we'll see before the holidays arrive, so be sure to keep on an eye out for the best deals.\xef\xbf\xbdSome of 2019's best tech gadgetsDisclosure:\xef\xbf\xbdZDNet\xef\xbf\xbdmay earn a commission from some of the products featured on this page. Jason Cipriani/ZDNet Apple AirPods Pro for $235Since the AirPods first launched in 2016, users and critics alike have been asking for noise cancellation and replaceable tips for a better fit. Apple finally delivered all of that and then some with the new AirPods Pro. The new design sounds better, will drown out background noise in noisy environments, and comes with three different sized tips to ensure you get the right fit. Nintendo Nintendo Switch Lite for $200 The smaller, more portable Nintendo Switch gives up the ability to slide into a dock and game on your TV, but it gains battery life and fun new colors. The screen has been shrunk to 5.5-inches, and the Joy-Cons are permanently attached to the device. But outside of that, it's still the same old Switch that users love and embrace.\xef\xbf\xbd Sonos Sonos Move for $400Sonos speakers have long been considered some of the best home entertainment speakers available, but they all had one problem -- they weren't portable. With Sonos Move, the company created a speaker that sounds as good as the rest of its lineup, but it's completely portable. You can use Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, or Apple's AirPlay 2 to stream music through the Move, regardless of how close the nearest power outlet is.\xef\xbf\xbd Amazon Amazon Echo Buds for $130In many ways, 2019 was the year of wireless earbuds. Amazon's Echo Buds have been well received and cost far less than Apple's AirPods Pro. The earbuds have Alexa built-in, have active noise cancellation, and work with iOS and Android devices.\xef\xbf\xbd Apple, Inc. Apple iPhone 11 Pro Max\xef\xbf\xbdfor $999The iPhone 11 Pro Max wasn't supposed to blow us away, but that's exactly what it did. Apple not only caught up with its camera features, but it's done an amazing job with new features like Night Mode. Then there's the fact that battery life on the 11 Pro Max is simply the best on any phone you can get this year.\xef\xbf\xbd Jason Cipriani/ZDNet Samsung Galaxy Note 10 Plus for $840Arguably the best Android phone of 2019, the Note 10 Plus is well designed, has a long list of features and capabilities, and is powerful enough to keep up with whatever you throw at it. It has plenty of cameras to harness your creativity, and, of course, it has that S-Pen that users know and love.\xef\xbf\xbd DJI DJI Mavic Mini for $399The Mavic Mini is the ideal combination of a capable drone in a small package. With a range of up to 4km and battery life of 30 minutes, it's pretty hard to believe it's priced at $399. It's perfect for those new to drones and enthusiasts who love shiny new things.\xef\xbf\xbd Fossil Fossil Hybrid HR smartwatch for $195The Fossil Hybrid HR is billed as a smartwatch, but could easily pass as a normal watch. Underneath the physical watch hands is an energy-efficient display that sips on battery yet still provides notifications from your connected phone, as well as weather and calendar details.\xef\xbf\xbd Wyze Wyze Sense Starter Kit for $20Know when a window or door opens, or whenever there's motion in the hallway with the Wyze Sense starter kit. You'll need one of Wyze's security cameras to connect it all to the internet, but those are just as cheap as this kit.\xef\xbf\xbd Amazon Amazon Echo Dot with clock for $45One of my top requests to Amazon's Alexa is to ask for the current time. The new Echo Dot with a clock eliminates that by adding a small digital clock to the side. You can still ask for the time, of course, or use Alexa to control connected devices, ask questions or play music.\xef\xbf\xbd Ring Ring Indoor Cam for $60Ring security cameras are some of the best, but up until now, they'd all been made primarily for outdoor use. The new indoor camera is affordable and capable of helping you monitor your home.\xef\xbf\xbdLet's be honest, distilling down the past year's worth of gadget launches into a shortlist is hard. Really hard. Surely, we left some of your favorite gadgets off of this list. Leave a comment and let us know what your favorite gadget of 2019 is.  Best gifts for co-workers under $50 on A... SEE FULL GALLERY                                                                                                                                                                                             \n"

612cd29826624e68ce96789c8049e16279dfd2fc.articleBody: b'  Tested by: John Milbank RRP: \xef\xbf\xbd23.99\xef\xbf\xbdMore info: www.clymer.co.ukI\x19ve worked on my own vehicles since I was 17 (I wish I still had that MkII Ford Escort), but this is my first time with a Clymer manual. I\x19ve got to say, I\x19m impressed! The level of detail is superb, with very clear diagrams and instruction \x13 particularly useful are the exploded drawings which feature regularly, and really help you to see how things come apart (and go back together).I was a little wary at the title of this book \x13 described as for the \x18CBR600F4\x19, this is of course the US version of the Honda I own. I needn\x19t have worried \x13 the UK bikes are fully covered, with all wiring diagrams and other areas clearly labeled for each market.Working on your own bike can be incredibly rewarding, so besides the fact that these manuals can save you a small fortune, the gratification of servicing and maintaining your motorcycle make them worth every penny (and they more than pay for themselves even with a simple oil-change).Get Motor Cycle Monthly delivered through your letterbox every month. 12 issues for \xef\xbf\xbd11.99. Click here for more information. Tell us what YOU think... comments\n'

624fcd903d56fc7055fa7097b330629450c095ad.articleBody: b"This comes after police said the demonstrators inside the Polytechnic University in Hong Kong had no option but to come out and surrender. The protests began peacefully in June and were sparked by proposed legislation that would have meant criminal suspects could be extradited to the mainland. Although the bill was withdrawn, the protests had broadened into a resistance movement against the territory\x19s government and Beijing.Many of the protesters wear masks to shield their identities for protection.China\x19s ambassador to Britain accused the UK and the US of meddling in the country\x19s affairs and warned that the Chinese government \x1cwill not sit on our hands\x1d if the Hong Kong situation \x1cbecomes uncontrollable\x1d.Cheuk Hau-yip, the commander of Kowloon West district, said: \x1cThese rioters, they are also criminals. They have to face the consequences of their acts.  China has warned they will cease control of Hong Kong (Image: GETTY )  The protests kicked off in June and have strengthened in size (Image: GETTY )\x1cOther than coming out to surrender, I don\x19t see that there\x19s any viable option for them.\x1dChina\x19s ambassador to Britain Liu Xiaming has said that China has the \x1cresolution and power\x1d to end Hong Kong unrest amid protests.Liu said that the People\x19s Liberation Army could be deployed in Beijing, warning: \x1cThey are already there in the Hong Kong garrison. They are there to show sovereignty and are responsible for defence purposes.SEE MORE:\xef\xbf\xbdHong Kong protests: 800 students under siege in university  Protesters do not want Hong Kong to lose its autonomy (Image: getty )\x1cIf the situation becomes uncontrollable, the central government certainly would not sit on our hands and watch. We have enough resolution and power to end the unrest.\x1dThis comes as China has denounced a Hong Kong court ruling declaring the government\x19s mask ban unconstitutional.This decision has been seen as \x1cseriously weakening\x1d the power of the Hong Kong chief executive.Chris Tang, Hong Kong\x19s new police commissioner, said in an interview that police alone are not able to end the violence.DON'T MISSChina furious at Macron for Hong Kong protest jibe\xef\xbf\xbd[INSIGHT]|Lakers vs Nets: NBA make final decision on game amid China turmoil\xef\xbf\xbd[VIDEO]Hong Kong 'threatened with Chinese military intervention'\xef\xbf\xbd[REACTION]  Protesters have worn masks to protect their identities (Image: GETTY )Protesters believe the extradition bill is an example of Hong Kong\x19s eroding autonomy under Beijing.They worry China is taking back the freedoms given to Hong Kong when the UK returned the territory to China.Hong Kong police have laid siege to a university, pinning 800 students inside and threatened to use live ammunition on them, as the latest round of anti-government protests escalates.  The Hong Kong Protests - how they happened (Image: EXPRESS )China said it is committed to the \x1cone country, two systems\x1d formula granting Hong Kong autonomy, while the city\x19s police deny accusations of brutality and say they show utmost restraint.The UK has urged an \x1cend to the violence and for all sides to engage in meaningful political dialogue\x1d.\n"

63db31a161b3c5b64e88c2978635cbc38d342ba8.articleBody:
b' Even if its core components are owed to other games, Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order finds a reason for their inclusion and stops just short of greatness. Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is game that is many things to different people. You can reductively call it Star Wars Uncharted; you do a fair bit of climbing on the side of buildings looking for a ledge to hold onto as you plan your next jump.
It\x19s Star Wars Souls, with tactical combat that requires careful blocking, dodging and occasionally parrying to get the most of. Perhaps it\x19s even Star Wars Raider, with its own self-contained puzzle areas that are literally ancient tombs.
Where it\x19s easy to view Fallen Order as an unoriginal mishmash of ideas, I instead see it as a successful attempt at marrying distinct systems from other games and presenting them in a coherent way.
Fallen Order\x19s story follows Cal Kestis, a Jedi-in-training forced into hiding as a young boy at the collapse of the Galactic Republic and the ensuing purge of the Jedi. The game\x19s entire story is motivated by events that occur in the prequel trilogy, but a cursory look at that era\x19s biggest moments is enough to get you on board with the premise.
One of the narrative\x19s strongest elements is that it doesn\x19t rely on iconic characters, or any major events beyond Order 66. Star Wars heroes like Obi-Wan are briefly shown or mentioned, without the usual reverence Star Wars fiction tends to bring to their appearances. There\x19s one exception to that towards the very end of the game, but it was unexpected, short and incredibly well-executed, but ultimately doesn\x19t matter to the general story.
After hooking up with a former Jedi (Cere) who blocked herself off from the Force, a loveable and high-strung ship captain (Greez), and an incredibly adorable little droid (BD-1), the four go on an adventure that would see them use Greez\x19s ship to travel to different planets chasing, well, McGuffins. With the exception of one late arrival, each of the four characters are given time to grow and evolve before the credits roll. BD-1, a droid who only speaks in bleeps and boops, is, for my money, this year\x19s best new character. 
I have to give special attention to his voice direction \x13 and my god, every little animation he plays \x13 both of which build up his character as an inquisitive, brave little robot. Respawn just has a thing for creating cordial robots. I will forever cherish this journey just as I do with Titanfall 2\x19s BT-7274.
The general setup of visiting the remnants of an ancient civilisation to obtain items or power intended to deal with a modern problem, only to find said civilisation had issues of its own, is familiar and ends up having little bearing on the narrative. The main force propelling me forward wasn\x19t so much the need to get the things, as it was to spend more time with these incredibly well-realised characters and visit alien planets.

You control where the ship goes, which opens up the game in wonderful ways. Taking inspiration from Metroid and Souls, many areas on these planets will only be accessible after obtaining certain Force powers. Dangling ropes require a pull, cracked walls require a push to crumble, and so on.
This means you\x19ll be travelling back and forth between the different planets even as more of them become accessible. The game certainly isn\x19t shy about sending you to one planet for a single mission, and off to another for the next, but you don\x19t always need to follow the quest marker if you don\x19t want to.
I visited Dathomir first, a mid-to-endgame planet. Got an important item just by exploring, before realising that most pathways are blocked, and that enemies are very tough. Clearly, I was in the wrong place at that point, but I managed to get something out of it. This very item is available at a different point through normal story progression, so it\x19s great to see Respawn offer players the freedom to obtain it so early.
As more areas of the different planets open up, zones become a complicated mess of shortcuts and multi-level structures. It\x19s not as elegant as you might find in FromSoftware\x19s work, which is what makes the map \x13 available to you at any point \x13 such a lifesaver.
The map makes it simple to plot a course, know which pathways are accessible and which aren\x19t. They\x19re even colour-coded so you know if the ones blocked off require an item or if they need to be accessed from the opposite end. It\x19s a more complicated version of Resident Evil 2 Remake\x19s map, and alleviates some of the frustrations players will have with navigating these enormous levels late-game. A fast travel system would take care of all problems entirely, but one doesn\x19t exist here. If you miss a shortcut, you could spend minutes trekking it across a massive area just to get back to your ship and watch a cutscene.
In your adventures, you\x19ll be mainly be attacked by three enemy factions. The wildlife: the most frustrating to fight because they\x19re often in groups, and have harder-to-read attacks. Then there are Stormtroopers, many of whom die in a single strike, though others more equipped to fight in melee will pose a bigger challenge. Neither of these are as demanding as the Purge Troopers, however \x13 units specifically trained to hunt Jedi.
Those not only offer the biggest challenge, they\x19re mostly armed with melee weapons, so understanding their attack patterns and responding in kind is more manageable.


The best new character in 2019.

Fallen Order occasionally tries to ramp up the difficulty by mixing the three together, and it can get infuriating trying to work your way through these sort of combat puzzles, which are often more tedious than they are difficult.
You\x19re going to parry the basic trooper\x19s bolts back at them, killing them in one hit. You\x19ll watch for the melee trooper\x19s very obvious tells to also get rid of them very quickly, and you\x19ll use whatever Force powers you might have to push some off a cliff or slow down the rest so you can better control the crowd. After all is said and done, you\x19ll be left with one or two Purge Troopers, only then can you have your duel and hopefully walk away victorious. 
I understand that these sort of encounters exist to allow players to live out the power fantasy, but on the two hardest difficulties (I finished it on Master), you\x19re not given enough leeway for that. You need to approach it as you would a Souls fight because you have different considerations than someone playing The Force Unleashed 2019.
A better way to handle that would have been to leave fodder enemies to the lower difficulty, and declutter the encounters for the higher ones. I would love to have spent much of my time duelling Purge Troopers, but now I have to get stun-locked for taking too many consecutive blaster shots.
Fallen Order\x19s combat borrows from Souls and Sekiro, but evidently sets its own rules. You don\x19t have a stamina meter, so you can wail on an enemy essentially forever, although most enemies can block.
You and your enemies all have a block meter, which drains the more hits are blocked. After it depletes, you\x19ll need to disengage until it recharges, or go on the offensive. It\x19s a simple enough setup that also allows for quick-stepping and full-on rolling, leaving you many avenues to escape danger. Where it falters is the execution. 
Enemy attacks track you a little too well, and can sometimes catch you through your roll or dodge. When this happens enough times, you\x19ll begin defaulting to just holding the block button and waiting it out. This is certainly viable, but it\x19s boring. The trick is instead in learning which attacks to roll through and which to block, which would make sense for a boss fight, but some consistency is required when fighting regular enemies.
Another problem is how the game handles parrying, which you can do if you time it right. Parrying an attack in most action games is a major moment in a fight. There\x19s often a loud sound cue and visual effects that trigger when you pull one off. Your opponents\x19 guard will, too, be left open for a brief moment as a result of the parry. 
Fallen Order has a different, clunkier approach. The time it takes to get into the blocking stance is unnecessarily long, and you can\x19t cancel into a parry. This caused my parries to fail, even if I was confident I have the timing right. By the same token, enemies don\x19t really care about your parries, save for bottom-of-the-rung troopers. They\x19ll often continue their combo unabated and you\x19ll stand there taking damage wondering why your parries aren\x19t working.
Over time, I realised that the animation simply isn\x19t fast enough to keep up with enemy attacks, so I got into a routine of parrying one or two and blocking the rest. The game signals unblockables with a clear red glow, but I found that regular long combos can be even more deadly. In fact, it was often easier to interrupt these perilous attacks with a Force push and use that window to attack. 
These little inconsistencies add up, and could\x19ve soured me on the game if Force powers and some of the more elaborate Lightsaber moves didn\x19t hook me. 

Which brings us back around to execution. The different shortcomings in traversal that lead to perfectly safe jumps failing for no good reason, the limited field of view when sliding that causes you to misjudge leaps, and the aforementioned combat could all \x13 at the game\x19s worst moments \x13 lead to frustration. Respawn clearly needed more time to brush off some of those edges, and it may get there eventually \x13 but right now, lack of polish is holding Fallen Order back. These imperfections weren\x19t enough to knock down my enjoyment, and I\x19ve certainly ran into far fewer technical issues compared to players on consoles, but they will for many. But Fallen Order is a confident, focused game whose individual pieces try, even if they don\x19t always win. 
The action may not be as exhilarating as the games Fallen Order is inspired by, its controls may not be as delicate, or its difficulty exacting \x13 but Respawn dares; shooting for something worthy of being mentioned alongside those hallowed inspirations.
And yes, it doesn\x19t always get there in this one, but damn If I can\x19t help but respect the effort. Fallen Order is a game whose worst moments are serviceable, and best moments are memorable. It\x19s worth experiencing by Star Wars fans hungry for an original story that doesn\x19t settle for trite, and action game players looking for a decent \x13 albeit flawed \x13 combat.
Version tested: PC.
